author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 19

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 22
text: (a) Prophecy, in its wider and general meaning, is the telling forth, by God's servants, of what He has revealed to them, whether this relates to past, present, or future.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 22
text: (a) Prophecy, in its wider and general meaning, is the telling forth, by God's servants, of what He has revealed to them, whether this relates to past, present, or future. But the word "prophecy" is also used in the narrower sense of prediction or foretelling the future.

But the word "prophecy" is also used in the narrower sense of prediction or foretelling the future. (h) A prophet is one who speaks of God to men.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 23
text: (a) A Miracle may be described as an intervention by God in what men have learned to look upon as the established course of nature. (b) The possibility of miracles cannot but be admitted by those who believe in the living God.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 35
text: Attributes of God. "We believe that there is only one God, who is infinitely perfect, the Creator, Preserver, and Governor of all things.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 35
text: "We believe that there is only one God, who is infinitely perfect, the Creator, Preserver, and Governor of all things.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 40
text: God is the Creator, Preserver, and Governor OF ALL THINGS. (a) As Creator, He brought into being and into order all that exists.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 35
text: Nature teaches the Existence of God. (a) The existence of natural objects shows that they must have had a Maker, for there can be no effect without a sufficient cause.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 35
text: Just as we know that a watch, a house, or a book must have been made by some man capable of producing it, so we know that the world and the universe, with all their wonders, must have had a Maker, and that He must have been very much higher and greater than man. This Maker we call God.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 35
text: This Maker we call God. (b) Further, Nature shows marvellous evidence of design or adaptation of means to end; for instance, the eye is adapted to receive light, the lungs to breathe air, fishes to swim, birds to fly.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 38
text: Since God is a Spirit He cannot be perceived by the bodily senses, but He can be known and understood by man's spirit.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 38
text: (b) Infinite means boundless or without limit. God alone is infinite. None can understand how great He is; none can measure or get to the end of His wisdom, power, or anything else connected with Him.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 38
text: (b) Infinite means boundless or without limit. God alone is infinite. None can understand how great He is; none can measure or get to the end of His wisdom, power, or anything else connected with Him. On the other hand, man is finite; everything about him is limited.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 39
text: Perfect Wisdom—He does everything in the best way, and never makes a mistake. Wisdom is the right use of knowledge; hence the perfect wisdom of God implies omniscience, but is more than omniscience.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 39
text: Wisdom is the right use of knowledge; hence the perfect wisdom of God implies omniscience, but is more than omniscience.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 89
text: This passage means that God foresaw who would receive Jesus, and predestinated that those who did so should be made like Him, and also that those who persevere in His choice or call should be finally justified and glorified.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 90
text: This verse follows the parable of the Marriage Feast, and means that God calls and wants all to be saved, but that only a few are chosen, because only a few are willing to comply with God's conditions; just as the king wanted all to partake of the feast, but could only choose those who put on the wedding garment.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 91
text: God's Salvation is for all, but man must comply with God's conditions; he cannot be forced into goodness in this life, and there are no grounds for believing that he can in the life to come.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 91
text: It is a mistake, therefore, to assume, as some do, that because Christ died for all, all must necessarily be saved, or to conclude, as do, others, that God has chosen to save or damn men regardless of how they act themselves. 6.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 92
text: At the same time, it must be clearly understood that no man can do or suffer anything, either before or after conversion, to merit Salvation in any way. The Only Ground or Merit of our Salvation from first TO LAST IS TO BE ASCRIBED TO THE LOVE OF GOD, AS DISPLAYED in the Work and Sacrifice of Jesus Christ.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 92
text: The Only Ground or Merit of our Salvation from first TO LAST IS TO BE ASCRIBED TO THE LOVE OF GOD, AS DISPLAYED in the Work and Sacrifice of Jesus Christ. All good in man is the work of God, but the good which God seeks to accomplish can only actually take place if man surrenders himself to God's gracious influences.

text: All good in man is the work of God, but the good which God seeks to accomplish can only actually take place if man surrenders himself to God's gracious influences.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 44
text: This truth should not, however, be doubted because it is mysterious, for— (a) Since God is infinitely greater than man, there must be that about Him which man can neither find out by searching nor understand fully even when it is revealed.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 44
text: This truth should not, however, be doubted because it is mysterious, for— (a) Since God is infinitely greater than man, there must be that about Him which man can neither find out by searching nor understand fully even when it is revealed. (b) Though the truth is beyond, it is not contrary to our reason.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 44
text: It is impossible adequately to picture, by means of material things, the profoundest truth concerning the Supreme and Infinite Spirit. 8.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 44
text: He is the Father of all men, for He is the source of their being; He owns them, loves and cares for them, and seeks their welfare.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 87
text: He has, so to speak, at tremendous cost, provided a "bridge" across the otherwise impassable chasm between sin and Salvation. But the sinner must himself use the way or "bridge" if he is to be saved. Should he neglect or refuse to do so he will be lost in spite of all that Christ has accomplished.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 112

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 112
text: By law alone no mercy can be shown to the guilty; he must be punished. But in virtue of Christ's sacrifice, God, as Righteous Judge, does justice to that sacrifice, by pardoning, in mercy, the believing penitent.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 41
text: The responsibility for such suffering cannot be placed on God. He is one of the many who suffer from the consequences of sin; perhaps it will turn out at last that He was the greatest sufferer of all.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 79

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 80
text: VI Just as an earthly ruler cannot but be the enemy of those who rebel against his authority, so God, the righteous Ruler of the universe, cannot but be against those who break His laws, and justice requires that He shall punish them.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 80
text: VI Just as an earthly ruler cannot but be the enemy of those who rebel against his authority, so God, the righteous Ruler of the universe, cannot but be against those who break His laws, and justice requires that He shall punish them. The great obstacle to reconciliation is God's antagonism to sin.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 73
text: The word Redemption signifies buying back or delivering by means of a ransom or price; that is, by the offering a sacrifice. Thus, man is redeemed from the claims of a broken law, from sin, Satan, and Hell, by the obedience and sacrifice of God's own Son.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 73

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 51
text: The Experience of those who are truly saved shows that Jesus must be God. We know that we are forgiven through faith in the merits of Jesus Christ's sacrifice; and we know, too, that this would have been insufficient to atone for sin had He been merely man.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 51
text: The Experience of those who are truly saved shows that Jesus must be God. We know that we are forgiven through faith in the merits of Jesus Christ's sacrifice; and we know, too, that this would have been insufficient to atone for sin had He been merely man. Hence we are convinced that He must be God.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 51
text: We know that we are forgiven through faith in the merits of Jesus Christ's sacrifice; and we know, too, that this would have been insufficient to atone for sin had He been merely man. Hence we are convinced that He must be God.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 67
text: God, as the Holy One and the upholder of the moral order of the universe, cannot but be against sin, although He loves and pities the sinner. In wrath or righteous anger, He hates, condemns, and must at last punish sin—unless some way of forgiveness be found (see Chapter VI, "Redemption").

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 67
text: In wrath or righteous anger, He hates, condemns, and must at last punish sin—unless some way of forgiveness be found (see Chapter VI, "Redemption").

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 104
text: Salvation is by Grace. Grace (in this sense) means the undeserved love of God, which, in virtue of the sacrifice of Christ, freely flows out in mercy and help to the penitent and believing sinner.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 104

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 109
text: The only ground or foundation of Saving Faith is the sacrifice of Christ. Although the sinner repents and believes as God directs, he is not saved by doing this, but only because Christ died for him.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 109
text: The only ground or foundation of Saving Faith is the sacrifice of Christ. Although the sinner repents and believes as God directs, he is not saved by doing this, but only because Christ died for him. (c) A measure of intellectual faith must precede Saving Faith.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 27
text: (d) We believe the whole Bible to be inspired, though not necessarily all parts of it in the same way or in the same degree. 3.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 29
text: The New Testament was not written until after Jesus Christ had left the earth. We cannot, therefore, appeal to His testimony to its inspiration as in the case of the Old Testament.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 29
text: The New Testament was not written until after Jesus Christ had left the earth. We cannot, therefore, appeal to His testimony to its inspiration as in the case of the Old Testament. We must find in the New Testament itself its own claim to its inspiration (see (b) iii of this paragraph).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 102
text: "We believe that repentance towards God, faith in our Lord Jesus Christ, and regeneration by the Holy Spirit are necessary to Salvation.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 102
text: (a) "Salvation," or "being saved"—in its narrower meaning—signifies the work which God at once accomplishes in and for the sinner who yields to Him. It includes— i. Forgiveness of sins. ii. Conversion, or Regeneration. iii.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 142
text: We believe that God's People may be delivered from All Sin and enabled to do God's Will continually in This Life. Many people do not agree with this, but maintain that they must go on sinning and repenting

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 101
text: (b) He should believe constantly that the Holy Spirit is working with him. (c) He should walk in harmony with the Divine Spirit; that is, he must be holy, as God is holy.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 101
text: (b) He should believe constantly that the Holy Spirit is working with him. (c) He should walk in harmony with the Divine Spirit; that is, he must be holy, as God is holy. (d) He should live for the same purpose as the Holy Spirit—the glory of God and the advancement of His Kingdom.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 127
text: (c) Faith makes eternal things real to us, and is the means by which spiritual needs are met. Faith is to the soul what the senses and other powers are to the body.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 142
text: We believe that God's People may be delivered from All Sin and enabled to do God's Will continually in This Life.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 146
text: To this we answer that it is true the subject is seldom written or spoken about and that comparatively few enjoy the experience, while many do not believe in it. At the same time our standard must not be the opinions or attainments of men, but the Word of God, which, in many ways, shows Holiness to be possible.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 155
text: Sanctification is the Work of God. Man's consecration and faith do not sanctify; they are simply conditions upon which God's sanctifying grace is given. 8.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 155
text: Sanctification is the Work of God. Man's consecration and faith do not sanctify; they are simply conditions upon which God's sanctifying grace is given. 8. Entire Sanctification takes place instantaneously—in the same sense that death takes place instantaneously.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 74
text: The Ground, Reason, or Foundation Cause of Redemption is the Love of God. The sacrifice of Christ was not the cause of God's love for sinners, or of His gracious disposition towards them.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 74
text: The Ground, Reason, or Foundation Cause of Redemption is the Love of God. The sacrifice of Christ was not the cause of God's love for sinners, or of His gracious disposition towards them. It was the outcome of that love.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 74
text: The Ground, Reason, or Foundation Cause of Redemption is the Love of God. The sacrifice of Christ was not the cause of God's love for sinners, or of His gracious disposition towards them. It was the outcome of that love. All along God loved and pitied sinners, but sin hindered the outflow of His favor to the world.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 74
text: The sacrifice of Christ was not the cause of God's love for sinners, or of His gracious disposition towards them. It was the outcome of that love. All along God loved and pitied sinners, but sin hindered the outflow of His favor to the world. His love led Him to devise means for man's deliverance.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 74
text: It was the outcome of that love. All along God loved and pitied sinners, but sin hindered the outflow of His favor to the world. His love led Him to devise means for man's deliverance.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 122
text: God keeps His People conditionally; that is, they must do their part if He is to do His. The Conditions OF CONTINUING IN THE FAVOR OF GOD ARE Obedience and Faith.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 122
text: God keeps His People conditionally; that is, they must do their part if He is to do His. The Conditions OF CONTINUING IN THE FAVOR OF GOD ARE Obedience and Faith. In repentance a man determines to obey God; in obedience he carries out that determination.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 134
text: The Sanctification of God's People means their Separation from Sin and their Devotion to God. The word "sanctification" always includes the twofold idea of separation and dedication (or devotion).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 165

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 70
text: Being "dead in sin" does not imply unconsciousness or absence of will power; it means that sinners are as powerless to save themselves from the corruption of sin as a corpse is to rescue itself from decay. iii.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 71
text: Many admire, and in their own strength seek, to live a life of benevolence, but, being unable to stem and change the current of their own evil natures, they fail, and usually give up in despair. Jesus Christ is their only hope. 7.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 71
text: Jesus Christ is their only hope. 7. The Subject of Sin suggests Questions which man, with his present limited knowledge, can only partially answer.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 71
text: The answer is that God must also have foreseen that greater good would, in the long run, result to the universe by allowing man to live and by providing for his redemption.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 71
text: The answer is that God must also have foreseen that greater good would, in the long run, result to the universe by allowing man to live and by providing for his redemption. Were this not so, God, being benevolent, would either not have created man, or would have destroyed him immediately after he fell.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 159
text: Although no attempt is made to satisfy mere curiosity, and many questions must evidently remain unanswered until the veil is withdrawn which now hides the unseen, yet sufficient is revealed for man's guidance, encouragement, and warning. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 170
text: Consequently, the vindication of the saved and the condemnation of the unsaved cannot be completed, until, as a result of judgment, a divine verdict has been pronounced which overrides and silences all other verdicts.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 23
text: (b) The possibility of miracles cannot but be admitted by those who believe in the living God. The Upholder and Director of all things can surely vary His usual way of working, causing events to take place in accordance with some principle unknown to man, if a wise and important end is to be attained thereby.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 24
text: Christ's Resurrection was one means of the founding and spread of Christianity. The disciples were entirely changed after seeing their risen Lord.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 24
text: Christ's Resurrection was one means of the founding and spread of Christianity. The disciples were entirely changed after seeing their risen Lord. They boldly preached Him in Jerusalem, the very stronghold of their enemies, which would have been impossible had they stolen His body.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 42
text: God exists as Trinity in Unity, or Three-inOne. This means that there are Three Persons in the Godhead—the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit; yet there are not three Gods, hut one God. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 42
text: Divine names and titles are therein given to each of the Three Persons; divine works are said to be done by each : divine worship is given and

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 43
text: In Pauls statement about the gifts of God's people. "Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit. And there are differences of administrations, but the same Ford. And there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God, which worketh all in all" (1 Corinthians xii. 4-6).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 43
text: "Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit. And there are differences of administrations, but the same Ford. And there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God, which worketh all in all" (1 Corinthians xii. 4-6).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 43

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 43
text: The Word "Person," when used in connection with the Trinity, should not be understood to mean an individual entirely separate from all others, as it does when speaking of human beings. The Three Persons are One in a sense that we cannot understand.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 43
text: The Word "Person," when used in connection with the Trinity, should not be understood to mean an individual entirely separate from all others, as it does when speaking of human beings. The Three Persons are One in a sense that we cannot understand. Jesus prayed

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 121
text: (c) Those who act up to the light they have will be accepted by God. That is, obeying the light is the condition of their Salvation, just as faith in Jesus is the condition of ours.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 121
text: That is, obeying the light is the condition of their Salvation, just as faith in Jesus is the condition of ours.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 121
text: That is, obeying the light is the condition of their Salvation, just as faith in Jesus is the condition of ours. But in both cases the ground or reason of acceptance is—not man's obedience or faith, as the case may be, but the atoning sacrifice of Christ.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 121

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 35
text: (b) Further, Nature shows marvellous evidence of design or adaptation of means to end; for instance, the eye is adapted to receive light, the lungs to breathe air, fishes to swim, birds to fly.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 37
text: Moreover, since provision has been made in the universe for the satisfaction of every other instinct of man's nature, we cannot believe that his religious and moral instincts alone are deceptive, and that there exists no divine reality to answer to them. 3.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 91
text: REDEMPTION 79 was intended to result in continual obedience and realization of the sprinkling of Christ's Blood. This election is, therefore, strictly conditional; it depends upon man's own conduct. 5.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 92
text: At the same time, it must be clearly understood that no man can do or suffer anything, either before or after conversion, to merit Salvation in any way.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 119
text: (b) The other witness is the man's ozvn spirit or conscience, which confirms the witness of the Spirit by telling him that— i.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 78
text: (a) Christ is described as a "Ransom," and His zvork as "Redemption "Ransom" is the price paid for the deliverance of a captive.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 78
text: (a) Christ is described as a "Ransom," and His zvork as "Redemption "Ransom" is the price paid for the deliverance of a captive. "Redemption" signifies deliverance brought about by means of sacrifice or ransom.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 78
text: (a) Christ is described as a "Ransom," and His zvork as "Redemption "Ransom" is the price paid for the deliverance of a captive. "Redemption" signifies deliverance brought about by means of sacrifice or ransom. Thus Christ, at the cost of His life, "redeems" or delivers us from sin and its penalty.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 78
text: "Redemption" signifies deliverance brought about by means of sacrifice or ransom. Thus Christ, at the cost of His life, "redeems" or delivers us from sin and its penalty.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 180
text: In the earliest days of the Organization, for a period of a few years an experiment was tried by the Founders in the use and administration of some of these ceremonials. They were, however, found to be a source of disagreement, and therefore a weakness.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 180
text: They were, however, found to be a source of disagreement, and therefore a weakness. Since no one would claim that any one or all of these ceremonies were necessary to the salvation of the soul, The Army left them behind and marched on with its work.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 181
text: (f) Sacraments cannot always be, as some of their advocates claim, u outward signs of inward grace," for it is clear that some who observe them possess but little, if any inward grace.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 181
text: (f) Sacraments cannot always be, as some of their advocates claim, u outward signs of inward grace," for it is clear that some who observe them possess but little, if any inward grace. It is equally clear that there are others who do not observe them who possess true inward grace.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 181
text: (f) Sacraments cannot always be, as some of their advocates claim, u outward signs of inward grace," for it is clear that some who observe them possess but little, if any inward grace. It is equally clear that there are others who do not observe them who possess true inward grace. BAPTISM 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 184
text: Here "born" and "water" are both typical, and signify inward cleansing, just as, when Christ promises to baptize with "fire," He means inward and spiritual—not outward, material fire.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 184
text: The Ends which the Advocates of Water Baptism claim to be fulfilled by this Ceremony are otherwise provided for in The Army. For example:-— (a) Infants are presented to the Lord by Dedication. (b) An "outward sign" of repentance is the penitent-form; "outward signs" of conversion are testimony and uniform-wearing.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 184
text: For example:-— (a) Infants are presented to the Lord by Dedication. (b) An "outward sign" of repentance is the penitent-form; "outward signs" of conversion are testimony and uniform-wearing.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 184
text: For example:-— (a) Infants are presented to the Lord by Dedication. (b) An "outward sign" of repentance is the penitent-form; "outward signs" of conversion are testimony and uniform-wearing. (c) Admission to Soldiership (or membership) is by signing Articles of War and public enrollment (or swearing in).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 184
text: (b) An "outward sign" of repentance is the penitent-form; "outward signs" of conversion are testimony and uniform-wearing.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 184
text: (b) An "outward sign" of repentance is the penitent-form; "outward signs" of conversion are testimony and uniform-wearing. (c) Admission to Soldiership (or membership) is by signing Articles of War and public enrollment (or swearing in).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 185
text: He explained that just as they partook of the food and drink which He handed them, so they must spiritually—that is, by believing— partake of His body and blood about to be sacrificed on their behalf.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 82
text: Christ's Resurrection and Ascension are the Crowning Proofs that the Atonement made by Him was Accepted. Had His sacrifice been faulty or insufficient the law would have detained its captive, and we could have had no hope of Salvation.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 82
text: Christ's Resurrection and Ascension are the Crowning Proofs that the Atonement made by Him was Accepted. Had His sacrifice been faulty or insufficient the law would have detained its captive, and we could have had no hope of Salvation. But the Father opened the door and broke the bonds of death which held the Saviour.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: REDEMPTION only provides a way for man's deliverance, but also makes clear to all how terrible is the evil which required so stupendous a sacrifice.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: (a) The death of Jesus Christ should not be represented as the literal payment of the sinner's debt. Sin is a "debt" only in the sense that man owes to God love and obedience, which, unlike a debt of money or property, cannot be paid by another.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: Sin is a "debt" only in the sense that man owes to God love and obedience, which, unlike a debt of money or property, cannot be paid by another.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: Sin is a "debt" only in the sense that man owes to God love and obedience, which, unlike a debt of money or property, cannot be paid by another. No other person could pay to a mother the love and obedience owing to her by her own child.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: Sin is a "debt" only in the sense that man owes to God love and obedience, which, unlike a debt of money or property, cannot be paid by another. No other person could pay to a mother the love and obedience owing to her by her own child. In fact, debt of this kind cannot be paid at all.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: No other person could pay to a mother the love and obedience owing to her by her own child. In fact, debt of this kind cannot be paid at all.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: No other person could pay to a mother the love and obedience owing to her by her own child. In fact, debt of this kind cannot be paid at all. Punishment of the wrongdoer would not pay it—he would still be owing what he ought to have rendered.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 83
text: In fact, debt of this kind cannot be paid at all. Punishment of the wrongdoer would not pay it—he would still be owing what he ought to have rendered.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 84
text: Of this The Army is most strongly convinced, although there are some who deny that Christ's atoning sacrifice has this all-embracing scope. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 84
text: Among Many Reasons for our Belief that Christ died for all Men are the following:— (a) From what we know of the character of God we should expect that He would include the whole race in His merciful undertaking.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 84
text: Among Many Reasons for our Belief that Christ died for all Men are the following:— (a) From what we know of the character of God we should expect that He would include the whole race in His merciful undertaking. Since He is both benevolent and just He would be neither so cruel nor so unfair as to leave out any.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 85
text: All agree that Christ died for those that will be saved; but since the Scriptures also state that He died for those who will perish, then Pie must have died for all. v.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 87
text: Christ, by His death, has opened a way of deliverance for all. He has, so to speak, at tremendous cost, provided a "bridge" across the otherwise impassable chasm between sin and Salvation. But the sinner must himself use the way or "bridge" if he is to be saved.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 87
text: He has, so to speak, at tremendous cost, provided a "bridge" across the otherwise impassable chasm between sin and Salvation. But the sinner must himself use the way or "bridge" if he is to be saved.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 111
text: The ground or reason of a sinner's forgiveness is the love of God as shown in the sacrifice of Christ. Forgiveness can never be merited by good deeds or by religious observances.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 112
text: "Justify" (as thus used) means to make or declare just (that is, righteous) in the sight of the law. An accused person is justified when declared by the judge righteous in the sight of earthly law; a sinner is justified when declared by God righteous in the sight of divine law.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 113
text: (e) Being justified or forgiven, means that the sinner is regarded and treated as righteous; consequently— i. He is free from the condemnation of the law.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 113
text: (e) Being justified or forgiven, means that the sinner is regarded and treated as righteous; consequently— i. He is free from the condemnation of the law. His sense of guilt is gone, and he is no longer exposed to punishment.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 113
text: Conversion, or Regeneration, is that great change which God the Holy Spirit works in the heart of a penitent sinner at the same time that He forgives his sins. (a) Conversion is of the nature of a nezv birth; it is the beginning of a new spiritual life, the soul starting life afresh, with everything new.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 113
text: (a) Conversion is of the nature of a nezv birth; it is the beginning of a new spiritual life, the soul starting life afresh, with everything new.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 113
text: (a) Conversion is of the nature of a nezv birth; it is the beginning of a new spiritual life, the soul starting life afresh, with everything new. That is:— The converted soul receives from the Holy Spirit new

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 115
text: ("The world" here means the spirit which animates the ungodly.) Their spirit, together with their aims, loves, enjoyments, and all else about them, is directly opposite to that of the world, and by the power of God they overcome the worldly influences by which they are surrounded.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 175
text: (e) Punishment must necessarily continue as long as sin, and it is evident that sin will go on for ever, for— i.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 175
text: (e) Punishment must necessarily continue as long as sin, and it is evident that sin will go on for ever, for— i. Men naturally tend to continue moving, morally and spiritually, in the same direction, unless hindered by some power outside themselves.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 175
text: Even in this life sinners reap, to some extent, the harvest of their sin—in misery, weakness, and hardness of heart. God's punishment of sinners simply means that He abandons them at last to the full consequences of their own evil character.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 175
text: God's punishment of sinners simply means that He abandons them at last to the full consequences of their own evil character.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 175
text: God's punishment of sinners simply means that He abandons them at last to the full consequences of their own evil character. Christ, as Judge, shows that condemned sinners are self-cursed, by His words to them as contrasted with His * "Annihilated" means done away with, or put out of existence.

text: Christ, as Judge, shows that condemned sinners are self-cursed, by His words to them as contrasted with His * "Annihilated" means done away with, or put out of existence.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 29
text: We cannot, therefore, appeal to His testimony to its inspiration as in the case of the Old Testament. We must find in the New Testament itself its own claim to its inspiration (see (b) iii of this paragraph).

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 53
text: The Word (or The Word of God) is a title showing Jesus Christ as the great Revealer of God. Just as a man reveals to another his thoughts, feelings, and even himself by means of words, so God reveals Himself to mankind by means of The Word—His Eternal Son.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 53
text: Just as a man reveals to another his thoughts, feelings, and even himself by means of words, so God reveals Himself to mankind by means of The Word—His Eternal Son.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 53
text: Just as a man reveals to another his thoughts, feelings, and even himself by means of words, so God reveals Himself to mankind by means of The Word—His Eternal Son. "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. . . .

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 54
text: (a) This title clearly indicates a unique relationship to God. That is, Jesus Christ is the Son of God in a sense far higher than that in which anyone else can be spoken of as a "son of God." This is shown in various ways: for example:— i.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 54
text: That is, Jesus Christ is the Son of God in a sense far higher than that in which anyone else can be spoken of as a "son of God." This is shown in various ways: for example:— i.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 67
text: God, as the Holy One and the upholder of the moral order of the universe, cannot but be against sin, although He loves and pities the sinner.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 67
text: God's righteous anger with sin must ever be distinguished from the personal or selfish anger of a private individual.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 68
text: (e) Sin is the root-cause of nearly all human misery. Affliction, poverty, war, death, and other sorrows can be directly or indirectly traced to sin, either in the individual or the race.
